para.paratext: Fed. R. Evid. 702 and O.C.G.A. § 24-7-702 provide that if scientific, technical, or other specialized knowledge will assist the trier of fact to understand the evidence or to determine a fact in issue, a witness qualified as an expert by knowledge, skill, experience, training, or education, may testify thereto in the form of an opinion or otherwise, if (1) the testimony is based upon sufficient facts or data, (2) the testimony is the product of reliable principles and methods, and (3) the witness has applied the principles and methods reliably to the facts of the case.[1] An expert witness is permitted wide latitude to offer opinions, including those that are not based upon first-hand knowledge or observation. The trial court has wide discretion in accepting or rejecting the qualifications of an expert, and the appeal courts will not disturb such ruling unless there is a showing that the trial court abused its discretion.[2] A witness need not necessarily be formally educated in the field at issue to be qualified as an expert.[3]

Georgia's 2005 Tort Reform Act, former O.C.G.A. § 24-9-67.1 (now O.C.G.A. §§ 24-7-702 and 24-7-703), split Georgia law regarding the admission of scientific evidence by applying different rules for the admission of expert testimony in civil and criminal cases.[4] Civil cases follow the test established by the United States Supreme Court in Daubert v. Merrell Dow Pharmaceuticals, Inc.[5] and criminal cases follow the more relaxed standard of State v. Harper.[6]
O.C.G.A. § 24-7-702(d) states:

It is the intent of the legislature that, in all civil proceedings, the courts of the State of Georgia not be viewed as open to expert evidence that would not be admissible in other states. Therefore, in interpreting and applying this Code section, the courts of this state may draw from the opinions of the United States Supreme Court in Daubert v. Merrell Dow Pharmaceuticals, Inc., 509 U.S. 579 (1993); General Electric Co. v. Joiner, 522 U.S. 136 (1997); Kumho Tire Co. Ltd. v. Carmichael, 526 U.S. 137 (1999); and other cases in federal courts applying the standards announced by the United States Supreme Court in these cases.

In Daubert, the United States Supreme Court identified five factors relevant to the inquiry into an expert's methodology: (1) whether the theory or technique can be or has been tested to see if it can be falsified, (2) whether the theory or technique has been subjected to peer review and publication, (3) whether there is a known or potential rate of error, (4) whether the methodology is subject to standards and controls, and (5) whether there is a degree of acceptance of the particular technique or methodology within the relevant scientific community. Under the requirements of Daubert, a court asked to admit scientific evidence must determine whether the evidence is genuinely scientific as opposed to being unscientific speculation offered by a “genuine scientist.”[7] A differential diagnosis satisfies a Daubert analysis if the expert uses reliable methods based on scientifically valid decisions regarding which potential causes should be “ruled in” or “ruled out.” Determining the reliability of an expert's differential diagnosis is a case-by-case determination.[8]

The United States Supreme Court, in Kumho Tire v. Carmichael,[9] reversed the Eleventh Circuit Court of Appeals and concluded that the Daubert holding applies to all expert testimony whether based upon scientific knowledge or upon “technical” or “other specialized knowledge.” The Court stated that the district court's exclusion of the tire failure expert's testimony, based upon the Daubert factors, was within the discretion of the trial court. The court observed that both scientific and non-scientific expert testimony is subject to the same admissibility requirements under Rule 702 and a witness who offers such testimony enjoys the benefit of “testimonial latitude unavailable to other witnesses” because they are assumed to have a reliable basis for their testimony within their respective fields of expertise. The Court reasoned that some of the Daubert criteria could be helpful in evaluating the reliability of expert testimony that was experience-based. Accordingly, a lower court might reject as unreliable experience-based expert methodology that produced erroneous results or other experts in the relevant field did not generally accept it.[10]

Interpreting Daubert and former O.C.G.A. § 24-9-67.1, the Court of Appeals reversed the trial court and held that it had abused its discretion when excluding expert testimony in a medical malpractice case where the expert testified that she arrived at her conclusion that the laboratory tech involved had breached the applicable standard of care by using one method and then using a second method to verify her findings. The trial court ruled that the second method involved did not satisfy the reliability requirements of Daubert. However, the trial court failed to consider the expert's alternative methodology for arriving at the conclusion. The Court of Appeals, citing Kumho, stated that the objective set forth in Daubert and in former O.C.G.A. § 24-9-67.1 is not to establish or enforce a particular methodology, but “to ensure the reliability and relevancy of expert testimony. It is to make certain that an expert, whether basing testimony upon professional studies or personal experience, employs in the courtroom the same level of intellectual rigor that characterizes the practice of an expert in the relevant field.”[11]

The well-known 1923 criminal case of Frye v. U.S.[12] preceded Daubert. In Frye, the United States Supreme Court set the initial standard for the admissibility of scientific evidence. Under Frye, the trial court determined that scientific evidence, such as a systolic blood pressure deception test, was admissible if the technique in question had gained “general acceptance in the scientific community which recognizes it.”

In Harper v. State,[13] the Georgia Supreme Court considered the problems that arose in applying the Frye test and concluded that the rule of “counting heads” within the relevant scientific community was not an appropriate way of determining the admissibility of a scientific procedure. The Harper court established a new procedure whereby the trial judge acts as a gatekeeper to ensure the reliability and relevancy of the evidence submitted and decides, “whether the procedure or technique in question has reached a scientific stage of verifiable certainty” or “rests upon the laws of nature.”[14] The trial judge may consider evidence submitted by the parties, including (but not necessarily limited to) expert testimony, exhibits, treatises, or the rationale of cases in other jurisdictions.[15] Once a procedure has been recognized in a substantial number of courts, “the judge may take judicial notice, without receiving evidence, that the procedure has been establish with verifiable certainty, or that it rests upon the laws of nature.”[16]

Georgia courts have employed the Harper standard to both admit and exclude various types of scientific evidence. For example, so many courts have recognized the following tests that they have been established with verifiable certainty: “microscopic, thin layer chromatography and Duquenois-Levine” lab tests for identifying marijuana;[17] and DNA, hair comparison, fiber comparison, and plaster tire track comparison evidence.[18] However, results from the following types of tests are inadmissible under the standard: truth serum tests[19] and penile plethysmography[20] (offered in child molestation cases to show arousal).

For years, it was unclear what type of evidence constituted “scientific evidence” for the purpose of applying the Harper test.[21] Finally, in Home Depot v. Tvrdeich,[22] the Georgia Court of Appeals plainly held that the standard should only be applied to evidence derived from scientific procedures or techniques. This seems to exclude any evidence which is derived from observation or is based on skill and expertise.

A party wishing to challenge expert testimony has an obligation to do so in a timely manner. Objections to an expert's qualifications should be made during a deposition taken for use as evidence at trial, since the proffering party might be able to cure objections at the time of the deposition.[23] A party seeking to rely on the expert bears the burden of proving the expert is sufficiently reliable. While the trial court is vested with broad discretion in deciding how to test an expert's reliability when determining whether to admit expert testimony, the weight given to such testimony is a matter for the jury to decide.[24]
Where an expert testifies, and there are contradictions in the expert's testimony, the jury must assess those contradictions, and such contradictions go solely to the expert's credibility.[25]

An expert cannot refuse to testify because he has not been or will not be compensated as an expert. He must obey a subpoena just as any other witness.[26] The Georgia Court of Appeals held in Nationwide Mut. Ins. Co. v. Glaccum,[27] that a chiropractor who testified as an expert witness was not entitled to extra compensation as an expert because a party did not ask him to conduct any preliminary examination or review his records.
However, an expert witness' opinion testimony that a victim was telling the truth constitutes improper bolstering and the inference to be drawn is not beyond the ken of the average juror.[28]

A court may also enter into evidence part of an expert's opinion while refusing to admit into evidence other portions of the testimony. In Clayton County v. Segrest,[29] the court held expert testimony regarding policy and procedures for high speed chases was required and admissible to assist the trier of fact since ordinary persons are not versed in such matters; however, the same experts could not testify that the officer “proximately caused” the crash, nor could they testify that he “recklessly regarded police procedure” as those phrases “speak to legal conclusions and would not assist the trier of fact.”[30]
Moore v. Cottrell, Inc., 334 Ga. App. 791, 780 S.E.2d 442 (2015); Graham v. Reynolds, 343 Ga. App. 274, 807 S.E.2d 39 (2017).
Burgess v. State, 292 Ga. 821 742 S.E.2d 464 (2013).
Mason v. Home Depot U.S.A., Inc., 283 Ga. 271, 658 S.E.2d 603 (2008).

Daubert v. Merrell Dow Pharmaceuticals, Inc., 509 U.S. 579, 113 S. Ct. 2786, 125 L. Ed. 2d 469, 37 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 1 (1993). However, note that a court sitting as a trier of fact in a confirmation hearing is not required to subject expert testimony as to value to a Daubert hearing. Harper v. Ameris Bank, 326 Ga. App. 67, 755 S.E.2d 872 (2014); Kershaw v. Princeton Properties Management, Inc., 348 Ga. App. 779, 824 S.E.2d 668 (2019).
See also Vaughn v. State, 282 Ga. 99, 646 S.E.2d 212 (2007).

See Garcia v. BRK Brands, Inc., 266 F. Supp. 2d 566 (S.D. Tex. 2003) (expert testimony not allowed as being “scientifically grounded speculation” when expert cannot conduct any reliable testing of its scientific theory and there was no indication that expert conducted any review of scientific literature in either researching challenged conclusions or preparing to defend them at the deposition or at the hearing).
Hawkins v. OB-GYN Associates, P.A., 290 Ga. App. 892, 660 S.E.2d 835 (2008).
Kumho Tire Co., Ltd. v. Carmichael, 526 U.S. 137, 119 S. Ct. 1167, 143 L. Ed. 2d 238, 50 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 1373 (1999).

See Metabolife Intern., Inc. v. Wornick, 72 F. Supp. 2d 1160 (S.D. Cal. 1999), decision aff'd in part, rev'd in part on other grounds, 264 F.3d 832, 57 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 347, 51 Fed. R. Serv. 3d 235 (9th Cir. 2001) (scientific evidence was not admitted because expert opinions were formulated for purposes of litigation and opinions not subjected to peer review).
Lavelle v. Laboratory Corp. of America, 327 Ga. App. 142, 755 S.E.2d 595 (2014).
Harper v. State, 249 Ga. 519, 525, 292 S.E.2d 389 (1982); Medical Center, Inc. v. Bowden, 348 Ga. App. 165, 820 S.E.2d 289 (2018).

Harper v. State, 249 Ga. 519, 292 S.E.2d 389 (1982). See e.g., Glidewell v. State, 279 Ga. App. 114, 630 S.E.2d 621 (2006) (overruled on other grounds by, Reynolds v. State, 285 Ga. 70, 673 S.E.2d 854 (2009)).
Cunrod v. State, 241 Ga. App. 743, 526 S.E.2d 900 (1999).
Gentry v. State, 213 Ga. App. 24, 443 S.E.2d 667 (1994).
Carr v. State, 267 Ga. 701, 482 S.E.2d 314 (1997). For this proposition, Carr stated:

The question of what type of evidence constitutes scientific test evidence which should be subjected to the Harper test has not been directly decided by the appellate courts of Georgia, but the test has been applied to a wide range of evidence: a possible genetic basis for violent and impulsive behavior in certain individuals (Mobley v. State, 265 Ga. 292(2), 455 S.E.2d 61 (1995)); breathalyzer tests (Lattarulo v. State, 261 Ga. 124(3), 401 S.E.2d 516 (1991)); the phenomenon of sleep talk (Godfrey v. State, 258 Ga. 28, 365 S.E.2d 93 (1988)); analysis of fibers (Williams v. State, 251 Ga. 749(1), 312 S.E.2d 40 (1983)); urinalysis for the presence of cannabinoids, using the SYVA EMIT 1000 test (Smith v. State, 250 Ga. 438, 298 S.E.2d 482 (1983)); penile plethysmograph evidence (Gentry v. State, 213 Ga.App. 24(2), 443 S.E.2d 667 (1994)); the “ontrack system” for detecting alcohol and controlled substances (Hubbard v. State, 207 Ga.App. 703, 429 S.E.2d 123 (1993)); horizontal gaze nystagmus test for intoxication (Manley v. State, 206 Ga.App. 281, 424 S.E.2d 818 (1992)); and the “child sexual abuse accommodation syndrome.” Rolader v. State, 202 Ga.App. 134(2), 413 S.E.2d 752 (1991).

Home Depot U.S.A., Inc. v. Tvrdeich, 268 Ga. App. 579, 602 S.E.2d 297 (2004). In Tvrdeich, the expert's testimony about his understanding of a disease was not based on any scientific test or particularize analytical technique, and thus the trial court was not required to apply the Harper standard to the evidence.

See also Orkin Exterminating Co., Inc. v. McIntosh, 215 Ga. App. 587, 452 S.E.2d 159 (1994) (Harper analysis did not apply to expert testimony about exposure to pesticides because the defendant “[did] not challenge a particular scientific test or technique employed by plaintiffs' experts; [rather, the defendant] challenge[d] the conclusions drawn by those experts from testimony and evidence in the record.)”; J.B. Hunt Transport, Inc. v. Brown, 236 Ga. App. 634, 635, 512 S.E.2d 34 (1999) (accident reconstructionist performed no test or technique; thus, Harper v. State did not apply to the expert's testimony that the defendant's negligence caused a wreck).
Jones v. Scarborough, 194 Ga. App. 468, 390 S.E.2d 674 (1990).
Medical Center, Inc. v. Bowden, 348 Ga. App. 165, 820 S.E.2d 289 (2018).
Moore v. Singh, 326 Ga. App. 805, 755 S.E.2d 319 (2014).
Schofield v. Little, 2 Ga. App. 286, 58 S.E. 666 (1907); Dixon v. State, 12 Ga. App. 17, 76 S.E. 794 (1912).
Polston v. Levine, 171 Ga. App. 893, 321 S.E.2d 350 (1984), held that an expert witness may demand a reasonable fee to testify at a deposition, unlike appearance at trial.
Nationwide Mut. Ins. Co. v. Glaccum, 186 Ga. App. 148, 366 S.E.2d 772 (1988).
Bowman v. State, 332 Ga. App. 766, 774 S.E.2d 805 (2015). See 7:8, infra.
Clayton County v. Segrest, 333 Ga. App. 85, 775 S.E.2d 579 (2015).
Clayton County v. Segrest, 333 Ga. App. 85, 92, 775 S.E.2d 579 (2015).
